availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

notesStmt.note: Contains Latin verses related to theses at Cambridge University.
Place and date of publication suggested by STC (2nd ed.).
Reproduction of original in the Cambridge University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: MINIMA VIS POTEST MOvere maximum pondus.

lg.l: TOlle reſiſtendi vim, ſi vis tollere rerum
Difficiles motus. Nam ſive moventibus addas,
Sive adimas aliquid motis, aequalia fient.
Res è ſede ſua rapidè ſubmota moventi
Se magis obfirmat, verùm ſileniùs illam
Moveris, invenies non tanta mole reniti.
Ergo reſiſtendi facilè minuenda poteſtas,
Si motu celeri minùs, & propiore quieti
Paulatim moveas: nam tardo tardior, illo
Tardior eſſe poteſt, & multo tardior illo.
Sic infinitis poterit vis illa reſiſtens
Diminui gradibus, nec vim ſuperare valebit
Motticem minimam. Capis haec? Ad caetera pergo.
Si data vis levior motrix admittere majus
Augmentum ſine fine queat, praegrandia tandem
Viribus aequabit, momentum nacta movebit.
At vis in vectes rotulaſue recepta paratas

Auctior efficitur, vireſ
que acquirit eundo.
Libram ſcis fieri radijs aequalibus▪ aequant
Res nullae niſi ſint aequali pondere libram.
In trutinis aliter, licet haud appenderis aequi-
Pondia, dum radius radio ſit longior, aequi-
Libria comperies. Oſtendam, concipe. Quantò
Grandius exiguo ſumpſiſti pondere pondus,
Majoris radium radius ſuperare minoris
Debet tantundem. ſic illa aequaliterambo
Pondera pendebunt, quamvis aequalia non ſint.
Si terrae mo • eat macilentus homuncio molem,
Quid dices? rides? equidem non ludo, movebit.
Vectis in extremo pendatur terra: Deinde
Sat prope ponatur ſtaterae hipomoclion. audin?
Motricem vim pone datam, ſint millia pondo.
Da terrae pondus, quantum vis ipſe: dediſti?
In partes radium majorem diuide, done •
Invenias toties radij brevioris in illo
Menſuram quoties numeratum in pondere grandi
Pondus habes levius. Levius tum pondus eidem
Appenſum radio, moturum dico minori
Appenſum radio terrae vix mobile pondus.
Haec ſi concipias quae ſum de vecte locutus
Cognoſces melius quod preſens 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 docebit.

Nonne rotas, axes, dentata
que tympana cernis?
Hae quatuor rotulae ſi centum millia pondo

Vilibrae vnius moveant quotcum
que libebit

Plures adde rotas, pondus quodcun
que movebis.
Ergo axis medio ſupremi intellige centrum

Staterae impoſitum▪ poſitum
que hypomoclionillic.
Staterae radius minor eſto diameter axis,
Dimidium vectis tranſmiſſi longior eſto,
Q •• decuplo maior decuplo maiora movebit
Pondera▪ tum verò, quia motis axibus ipſa
Circumſcripta ſimul moveantur tympana, primum
Fertur ab axe ſuo moto niſi pondere librae
Vnius, pondus decies tam grande valentis.
Iam porrò perpende rotam quam ſuſtinet axis
Proximus. In medio ponas hypomoclion, ac ſi
Efficeres trutinam velut antè: diameter axis
Sit brevior, rotulae ſit ſemidiameter alter
Staterae radius maior porrectusad axis
Supremi dentes, quorum rota prima rotatur

Contactu, ſecum
que ſuum circummovet axem:
Nacta decem decies librarum pondus ab illo
Majori radio decupla ratione minorem

Vincenti radium, centum
que movere valebit.

Quantumcun
que voles numero creſcente rotarum
Augetur vis prima movens ratione priori.

l.hi: Vim minimam gravium grandiſſima pondera rerum
Sic conſtet varijs poſſe movere modis.

lg.l: SIc dat agens formam▪ formam facit eſſe, parando

Aptam materiam diſpoſitam
que ſatis.
Propterea Chymicorem proprietatibus auri
Sufficit indutam diſpoſuiſſe probè.
Hoc ars pr • ſ • abit. nam quamvis caeteranon ſint
Cocta ſatis, non ſint pura metalla ſatis,
Ignis habet vires quae ſunt incocta coquend • ,
Impurum fieri purius igne poteſt.
Ergo tam purum reddetur vt induat auri
Naturam plumbum ſubveniente foco.
Porrò metalla vides ſimul omnia, proprietates
Tantùm diſtinctas, participare, gradu.

Pondus habent, poſſunt ducifundi
que , nitorem
Oſtendunt, ignis vim tolerare valent.
Caetera diſtinguit graduum diſcrimen ab auro,
Naturâ nihilo convenient minus.
Nec tanti res eſt haec tranſmuta • e laboris,
Principijs etenim ſunt propiora ſuis.
Adde quód in primam, qua facta fuere, reſolui
Materiam poſſunt artis & ignis ope.
Sulphur & argentum vivum ſunt omnia, quidni
Ars ea componat cùm reſoluta ſient?

Di • quid abeſt: ignis quaecun
que coquenda, libenter
Concoquit, & ſeparat quae ſeparanda putas.

Vis mineralis abeſt? ſed adeſt quo
que vis mineralis.
Hanc vim (n • valde fallor) elixir habet.
Ille lapis fiat purè. generabitur aurum.
Nam lapis aurific • ſeminis inſtar erit.
Num mir aris aquas èlignis ſaxa creantes?
Quin clamas fraudes eſſe, ſubeſſe dolum?
Non potes▪ & cur non plumbum vertatur in aurum?
Alchymiâ vires ſuppeditante ſuas?
At credenda magis vicina metalla metallis,
Quàm lapides lignis, res manifeſta nimis.
Pergimus hinc. Animal ſi fortè vel arte putreſcat.
Diver ſum ſpecie gignere ſaepe ſolei.
Eſt animatarum maior perfectio rerum,
Quàm quibus haud animae mica minuta datur.
Ergo minor laus artis erit, ſi fecerit aurum.
Eſt animal multo res operoſa magis.

Deni
que ſi quando veſcaris carne bovinae,
Corporis & carnis pars erit illa tuae.
Intus agens, extra chymico reſpondet agenti.
An-non fiet opus par ab agente pari?
Ad • o quòd obijciunt, Sciriproportio certa,
Et miſcendorum miſtio iuſta nequit.
Non opus eſt minimum praecisè quaerere punctum.
Non ſunt in certo pura metalla gradi • .
Addunt: Ille calor generans non igneus eſſet.
Caeleſtis potiùs debuit eſſe calor.
Eſſe calor poterit caeleſtis & igneus idem.
In ſpeculis radios vrere non-ne vides?
Aſt vterum proprium generanda metalla requirunt.
Auro igitur terrae viſcera danda. nego.
Fortuitos ſortita locos animalia naſci
Saepe ſolent vt ero quae caruere ſuo.
Hi • ergo liceat. pergunt. Minor eſſe videtur
In conſumendo quàm generando labor.
At purum nullis conſumitur ignibus aurum.
Non igitur fiet. Me nihil ista movent.
Ad primum nequeunt quae ſunt aſſata reduci.
Succum. tum falſum eſt quod poſuere p • iùs:
Et quod ſubſequitur: vi flammae abſumitur aurum
Tarde, ſed tandem, vel penetrantis aquae.

l.hi: Alchymiam non eſſe dolum, non eſſe doloſam
Credere, me prohibent paucula, multa iubent.
